natural problem: Find the greatest common divisor of $7!$ and $(5!)^2.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes factorial :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "factorial 0 = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. factorial (Suc n) = Suc n * factorial n"
shows  "gcd (factorial 7) ((factorial 5)^2) = 720"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the greatest common divisor of $7!$ and $(5!)^2.$ The final Answer is 720
 ### Proof
 $$ \begin{array}{rcrcr} 7! &=& 7 \cdot 6 \cdot 5 \cdot 4 \cdot 3 \cdot 2 \cdot 1 &=& 2^4 \cdot 3^2 \cdot 5^1 \cdot 7^1 \\ (5! )^2 &=& (5 \cdot 4 \cdot 3 \cdot 2 \cdot 1)^2 &=& 2^6 \cdot 3^2 \cdot 5^2 \\ \text{gcd}(7!, (5!
 )^2) &=& 2^4 \cdot 3^2 \cdot 5^1 &=& \boxed{720} \end{array} $$
 *)

theorem
fixes factorial :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "factorial 0 = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. factorial (Suc n) = Suc n * factorial n"
shows  "gcd (factorial 7) ((factorial 5)^2) = 720"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the greatest common divisor of $7!$ and $(5!)^2$. The final answer is 720.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = fact 7"
and h1 : "b = (fact 5) ^ 2"
shows  "gcd a b = 720"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the greatest common divisor of $7!$ and $(5!)^2.$ The final Answer is 720
 ### Proof
 $$ \begin{array}{rcrcr} 7! &=& 7 \cdot 6 \cdot 5 \cdot 4 \cdot 3 \cdot 2 \cdot 1 &=& 2^4 \cdot 3^2 \cdot 5^1 \cdot 7^1 \\ (5! )^2 &=& (5 \cdot 4 \cdot 3 \cdot 2 \cdot 1)^2 &=& 2^6 \cdot 3^2 \cdot 5^2 \\ \text{gcd}(7!, (5!
 )^2) &=& 2^4 \cdot 3^2 \cdot 5^1 &=& \boxed{720} \end{array} $$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = fact 7"
and h1 : "b = (fact 5) ^ 2"
shows  "gcd a b = 720"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the greatest common divisor (GCD) of the factorial of 7, denoted as 7!, and the square of the factorial of 5, denoted as (5!)^2. The final answer is 720.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b gcd :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = fact 7"
and h1 : "b = (fact 5) ^ 2"
and h2 : "gcd = gcd a b"
shows  "gcd = 720"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the greatest common divisor of $7!$ and $(5!)^2.$ The final Answer is 720
 ### Proof
 $$ \begin{array}{rcrcr} 7! &=& 7 \cdot 6 \cdot 5 \cdot 4 \cdot 3 \cdot 2 \cdot 1 &=& 2^4 \cdot 3^2 \cdot 5^1 \cdot 7^1 \\ (5! )^2 &=& (5 \cdot 4 \cdot 3 \cdot 2 \cdot 1)^2 &=& 2^6 \cdot 3^2 \cdot 5^2 \\ \text{gcd}(7!, (5!
 )^2) &=& 2^4 \cdot 3^2 \cdot 5^1 &=& \boxed{720} \end{array} $$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b gcd :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = fact 7"
and h1 : "b = (fact 5) ^ 2"
and h2 : "gcd = gcd a b"
shows  "gcd = 720"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Find the greatest common divisor (gcd) of the factorial of 7 ($7!$) and the square of the factorial of 5 ($5!^2$). The final answer is 720.

theorem
fixes a b gcd :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = fact 7"
and h1 : "b = (fact 5)^2"
and h2 : "gcd = gcd a b"
shows  "gcd = 720"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

fixes x y :: nat
